content.description: Climb the crack and continue up the face to a bolt.  Surmount the small overhang (crux, long reach) then finish on Tango or traverse right under the Violent Femmes overhang and finish on Gorilla.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Note that shifting rock on the Violent Femmes overhang poses potential danger for this route.
content.location: At a thin crack 8 feet left the left-facing corner that marks the start of Tango.

content.description:
P1 - Climb the left-facing corner to a small shelf below the huge overhang and some fixed pitons (shifting rock, potential rockfall hazard).   Traverse left along the shelf until you can pull into the left-facing corner above (crux, harder if short).  Continue up and right to a belay ledge. 

  P2 - Climb straight up the steep left-facing corner to the ceiling.  Clip the bolt, then surmount the ceiling on the right and up to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Note that shifting rock on the overhang poses potential danger for this route.
content.location: At a large, left-facing corner beneath a large overhang.

content.description:
P1 - Climb the crack approximately 20 feet to a small ledge and a band of crappy rock.  Climb past the shaley rock up a face to a bolt, then work up past more poor-quality shaley rock until you can move right to a nicve belay ledge (same as Tango). 

  P2 - Move a bit left, then up several "steps" to a large ceiling (easier than it looks).  Climb through the notch in the ceiling to the top.  Large cam helpful at the ceiling.
content.location: At a short crack about 6 feet right of the left-facing corner that separates the Neolithic Wall from the Tango Wall

content.description:
Note: This route was apparently destroyed when a large piece of Tango ceiling fell in 2005. 

  Climb Gorilla to the first large ceiling (=Tango ceiling).  Traverse left on the face out to the left edge of the face, then continue up, passing another ceiling on the left.  Move back right and up to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Note that shifting rock on the Violent Femmes overhang poses potential danger for this route.
content.location: Same as Gorilla.  8 feet right of the Tango left-facing corner.

content.description:
Climb the short right-facing corner or the overhangs to the left to a large corner with a piton.  Move up to the large overhang. 

  From here the original route had a 5.7 finish. 

  A freeze in winter 2005 removed a giant block from the Tango Roof, inadvertently upgrading Gorilla to a 5.11+ finish.
content.protection: Standard rack.  Note that shifting rock on the overhang poses potential danger for this route and may have altered the original grade (easier).
content.location: 8 feet right of the large left-facing corner (Tango).

climbs.name: Crummy Rotten Crack
climbs.fa: Mike Werner (1975).  FFA Bill Shaniman (1978 or 79)

content.description:
The first 5.10 route established at High Rocks.  

  Start as for Gorilla, then move right at the top of the initial corner to a thin overhanging crack just left of an outside corner.  Climb the crack past an old piton, avoiding the corner to the right, to the top

P1 - Climb the crack then move into a "cave-like" crack (crux).  Step up and right to a belay (same as Tango). 

  P2 - Traverse right around a corner and up to a ledge.  Either scramble easily off right to a belay at a tree or climb up the face to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack, a bit on the R side of things.
content.location: At a crack approximately 6 feet right of the Hummingbird crack (second crack to right on Trango Wall).

content.description: Tango Wall contains several classic climbs, including the hardest climbs at Ralph Stover.  Tango (5.8) is the classic on this section, but don't miss Hummingbird (5.6)
